subject: Re: [patchmanagement] KB5020276—Netjoin: Domain join hardening changes
email_text_original:
You don't often get email from bgonza868@gmail.com. Learn why this is important
[https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification] 
From the client side: The Domain Join operation is a privileged action initiated
by a local account (though, if the join status is dirty, and the current policy
set allows it, you can still log into the device locally, with a cached domain
account) on the machine attempting to join. The first interaction with the
domain is the computer account's. If there is a policy that prevents the account
from joining, that's where the operation stops. The user's account and groups
are not even checked. 
From the AD side: domain admin can delete/create computer objects freely but
that has nothing to do with the actual join operation, other than pre-arranging
the policy set by creating the account (instead of letting it join to the
default location) or doing a dirty dis-join by removing the computer object (or
disabling it) 
Bryan Gonzalez
Senior Software Engineer
battleface.com
